bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, November 26, 1941

div1.p: Truby responds to Hench's suggested corrections and additions to Truby's manuscript. He provides additional details, clarifies several points, and refers Hench to others who might be able to provide further information.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, November 26, 1941
div1.opener:
145 Laurel Street, San Francisco, Calif.
November 26, 1941
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Your Express package with various papers arrived on November 17th. Thank
you very much for your comments on the manuscript. They are most helpful
in bringing out points which an Army man would not realize might not be
fully understood by the average reader.

The most of the items need no comment here as they are clear to me. I
mentioned the title I like in my last letter to you and am awaiting your
comments on that.

Page 1023. Balascoaine Barracks were on or near a street of the same name.
I can't specify exactly.

Page 41. None of our sick were treated in wooden buildings during 1899
except those in the Receiving Ward and Venereal Ward, until the new hos-
pital buildings (91-93) could be used late in 1899 or early 1900. All
typhoids and other cases, except as stated above, were treated under canvas
on the flat area between 108 to 91-93.

Page 59. I did not know that Lambert and Moran had any trouble. I think
that they are both honest in their ideas about the past but both are mis-
taken about some things that I am sure of. Consequently, I have tried to
the best of my ability to quote them and all the others only when I feel
sure they have the right answer. Lambert does remember about the yellow
fever camp because that was his baliwick. Pinto has confirmed all of
Lambert's statements in the manuscript.

Page 71. I can't explain how I managed to get this paragraph “balled
up”. In the preceeding paragraph, I stated that Agramonte went to Pinar
and did an autopsy on the 19th. All the correct data were in General
Lee's report which I have. Possibly I was dumb when I was writing it
and looked up the date in the Senate Document and that led me astray.
Of course I knew July 31st was wrong for Reed and I sailed on August 2nd.
Agramonte's statements were correct; he quoted from official reports.
what is the ref to this report ✗

Page 83. When Pinto was here, he definitely fixed 116 as the hut where
Carroll was treated and 118 as Lazear's. I am satisfied that he is correct.
Page 83. Lazear remained in 106.

Page 85. My statement was qualified:- “Insofar as I can remember, the body
of Dr. Lazear was the last”- etc. I still think that we had no more yellow
fever cases at the Post or at Quemados after Lazear died. I said nothing
about cases from Havana. No doubt there were several from there, all of
them were of course interred in our cemetery. The Petersons, Page and
probably Halstead came from Havana where yellow fever was still raging.
Dr. Hench: 11-26-41

Page 88 (This is the wrong page number). I rather think that Dr. Pinto's
recollection about this matter is correct. I faintly remember that Ames
complained about both Carroll and Agramonte for not coming to see Lazear.
I feel, however, that neither Pinto nor I could consistently state that
Carroll did not see Lazear. Carroll was, I think, still convalescing in
116, only a few yards from 118, and may have seen Lazear. Under the cir-
cumstances, don't you think I had better leave it “as is”?

show
Pinto

Page 88. I am very glad you questioned this paragraph. Kean did not find
any fault with it in his comments on the manuscript. I thought I was quot-
ing him correctly. I will have to depend entirely on what he tells me
about this. I don't know where I got the date (September 25th) for I can't
confirm it. Lazear died at 8:45 P. M. September 25th. The cablegram report-
ing his death to the War Department probably got off from Quemados, Havana,
between 9:00 and 10:00 on the morning of the 26th. Therefore, if the trans-
port sailed at noon on the 26th, Reed would have left Washington before the
news reached General Sternberg. All I know about it personally is that
even though Reed had seen Kean and Havard at Matanzas, he knew very few
details when he reached us. That part is clear.
Page 90. They are practically identical.

Page 91. No. We said very little regarding Agramonte because of limited
time. He came about 10:00 A. M. and before noon, I took him to see General
DeWitt and he left shortly afterwards. I had time only to review with him
his statements which I had written up in my retained manuscript. He Okayed
them and by the time we had discussed our old friends generally, he had to
leave. Of course Pinto's tale about Dean refutes Agramonte's “All else is
pure fancy” story. Pinto has no reason to lie about his story and that story
has not changed since he told it to me in September 1900. You know that
my views about Agramonte are very well fixed, based on definite personal ob-
servations, so to you and others I would of course appear as too prejudiced
to qualify as a satisfactory investigator. Someone else must do it. Please
read your statements in your letter to me January 7th, 1941 and my reply
January 27th. I can find no errors in Agramonte's statements prior to
Carroll's death. Some of them, which you unearthed, should convince you
that his Dean story, written later (1915) in the Scientific Monthly, is very
strange. Therefore I am returning that paper to you without comment at
this time, so you can get Pinto's statements (and others including Dr.
Cooke) first. I was interested in your letter from New Orleans and your
interview with the venerable Matas. Sorry you did not let me know you were
going there for I would have suggested looking up Dr. De Poorter who came
from Louisiana. He may be living and perhaps would remember many of these
things. When you go to Washington, try to see Mrs. A. N. Stark who was
present when Lazear did his experiments in August and might have much
valuable information for you on this and everything else.
What
tale
--------
See my copy
of Pinto's note
to Truby
(p 91 T's mss)
# 3 my mss
Show Pinto

I wonder why you have never made any comment on my remarks in your Hammeter
book. I was perhaps too frank but it is the true picture as I saw it. I
hope you will not let my remarks stand alone. Please get some of the others
to add their views to Kean's and mine and then I would like to have you let
me see it again. While I would like my remarks to be considered confiden-
-2-
3
Dr. Hench: 11-26-41
tial, I don't mind letting you show them to Pinto, Cooke or Mrs. Stark.
They will promptly tell you if I am wrong in my estimate.

I am not “disregarding” any versions nor anxious to perpetuate “pure bunk”
but am going to tell what I think is the correct version. It is up to
the historians to analyze all the versions with the incentive behind them
and then draw conclusions. If my views are worthless, it won't matter.
I am not vindictive but I do hate to see what I think are deliberate false-
hoods perpetuated without a thorough study by an impartial investigator.
I think you have the incentive and are best qualified to do the job. Of
course you know that General Kean thinks the whole controversy should be
ignored.
Page 96. I am not inserting Pinto's statement regarding this.

Page 98. I am not sure about it but I do know that I did not see Agramonte
from September 18th until several days after Reed returned on October 4th.
I don't think it would have been possible for him to have seen Lazear dur-
ing the latter's illness without my knowing it and I think that Ames com-
plained about that very thing. I did not see him at Lazear's funeral. All
of this can be inferred from my remarks in the manuscript. Knowing of past
events in Cuba, I expect that it would be easy to produce plenty of wit-
nesses to state that they were with Agramonte at the funeral. Perhaps they
were but it would be hard to convince me on that point.

I see no reason why Carroll should have mentioned Agramonte's absence to
Mrs. Carroll unless he knew it was so. Agramonte must have been away some-
where; otherwise, if he was so important a member of the Board as he leads
one to think, would he not have taken over the work at the laboratory where
Steward Neate was left alone when Lazear became ill? Of course he would and
I would have known it for I was in command. I know that in all that time
Agramonte did not appear at the laboratory. I personally saw Neate and saw
that he was taking care of things in his usual efficient way. Of course
everything there was at a standstill with nothing but the cultures and mos-
quitoes to look after.

I do not think that contract surgeons at that time made personal reports
but all changes in their status had to be indorsed on their contracts. It
is possible that this contract had to be surrendered at the expiration of
service and, if so, Agramonte's may be found in the Surgeon General's Office
or the Adjutant General's Office. I think that a leave of absence would
appear on the contract. It is very important to find it or at least have
a thorough search made of Agramonte's record in both places. Mr. Brook,
Chief Clerk in the Surgeon General's Office, should be able to help you if
he is still there.
look up

Page 99. If Carroll's statement to his wife regarding Agramonte's absence
was not true, you may be sure that Agramonte would have denied it. then and
there in most forcible terms. This alone makes me feel that Carroll was
right.
Page 101. I explained that in my comments.
Page 103. I sent you the answer. DOUGHERTY.

Page 105. I don't think so. He spoke at a local banquet. Is it impor-
tant to find out before I quote from Baker's article? He told me to use
it in any way I liked.

Page 108. I selected Acting Steward Cook and the detachment of men to
work at the camp and made trips several afternoons with Reed, Ames and
others to see the work. I was there while buildings 1 and 2 were being
built and was inside of them on several occasions. When you need a
letter, you can have it.
get

Page 111119. Ames was already in charge before I left Columbia Barracks.
Why should you doubt the Board's statement which was written at the close
of the experiments? Moran was quarantined in a tent so that he might have
failed to see Ames. In the daytime when Reed was there, Ames might have
been away. It does not seem very important to me.

Page 132. Reed mentions it on page 80, Senate Document in the two para-
graphs above Case 6. They had volunteers available at that time, I think,
but Reed wanted to use them - Moran, for instance - on another experiment.
Beside the reference I have given you, I think there is still another one
but I can't find it now. I will modify my statement so that it can't be
questioned.

Page 133. Two non-immune volunteers stayed in the mosquito-free side of
the building. Reed, Ames, Carroll andsaw the mosquitoes bite Moran on eachone
occasion. There may have been a different group of spectators each time
but I dare say Reed was there every time. If Moran's statement regarding
Ames was true (page 119), why was Ames present? Reed depended on Ames
profesionally and you may be sure Ames was never away from that camp very
much.
Page 140. Yes, definitely.

Page 144. Yes. I shall, however, prepare a detailed statement for future
use in case it is needed. See previous remarks on this point.
get

Thanks for your suggestions regarding photographs. You will like some that
I have, nearly all taken by myself. I have not heard from Carlisle recently.

Referring to the Sick and Wounded Reports. I think the Surgeon General's
Office can help you find them. Every month such report were made out in
longhand in duplicate on large sheets of paper about 14×18″. Each case was
entiere[unclear]d upon admission, giving name, organization, rank, diagnosis, compli-
cations, etc. One of these sheets was retained at the hospital and the
other one went to the Surgeon General's Office. Whether this sheet went
elsewhere or not, I do not know. Mr. Brook or his successor in the Surgeon
get
-4-
5
Dr. Hench: 11-26-41
General's Office can tell you. General Kean may know as he told me he
once looked them up for some purpose. If found, they should be micro-
filmed for they contain most valuable information which is absolutely
correct.

I have too much reading matter on hand to read Dominguez's book now but
would love to see it later.

Yes. I know all about Lambert's attempts to get on the “Roll of Honor”.
That is quite natural but of course I don't agree with him. He is a
faithful, honest person and did splendid work without any idea of reward
at the time. He had a poor education and his letters are hard to follow,
but on some things I know he has stated facts. He is definitely confused
on a few things. His description of the yellow fever camp, before I
saw the maps you obtained from the War Department, was perfect in every
respect. Of all the enlisted men, Andrus gives the clearest and best
account of any. His memory is good and he writes extremely well. You
have never told me if he asked your permission to quote my account of
Lazear's death in your article last year at W & J. I asked him to do so
way back in February or March. Although I have heard from him since then,
he has not mentioned hearing from you.

Thanks for the copy of Carroll's letter to his wife. Is the magazine
“Janus” still in existence and is it O.K. for me to quote from Hammeter's
paper? Please advise me regarding this soon as I wish to complete that
chapter.
Many thanks again for your interest and help.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, Albert E Truby ALBERT E. TRUBY
Your inclosures returned herewith:
1 - copy of letter to Miss Wood
2 - Scientific Monthly (1915)
3 - Agramonte's letter to Hammeter
4 - Three (3) maps of Columbis Barracks 1899

div1.p: Truby comments
Page Six.

(32) Yes, I am positive. My statement could even be stronger.
The board had planned to start work on three things, viz:- Finish the
study of the Sanavrelli organism, make a study of the intestinal flora,
and test the mosquito theory. Reed and Carroll had worked a long time
on the first and it was quite urgent for them to finish that first.
Reed placed Lazear in charge of the mosquito work, but you may be quite
sure that Reed was deeply interested and always had the case of the pris-
oner at Pinar del Rio in his mind. That was his own observation, and shows
how keen he was about “the theory”. Lazear's letter stating “Reed was not
yet interested in the mosquito work”, (quoting from you) must not be mis-
interpreted. Could it not mean that Reed was not yet ready to take up that
work because the other job had to be finished first? I think so. I think
Lazear was impatient that the other two did not join him in pressing the
mosquito theory to a rapid conclusion, (Lazear was undoubtedly optomistic
about it) and reasoned that if they obtained positive results with the mos-
quito the other theory (Sanavrelli) could be scrapped then and there. Look-
ing at it with our present knowledge that would have been the thing to do.
It was not the logical thing for Reed then, for he was in the midst of the
long bacteriological study which was nearing conclusion, and in the midst
of his controversy with Wasdin and Geddings. As for the “germ” mentioned,
which Lazear was also trying to find, you must remember that they did not
know about a virus at that time. Lazear's work was not “unknown” to Reed.
Did he not provide Lazear with every facility, including the assistance of
his personally trained assistant, Steward John Neate? And do you think
Reed was the kind of a man who could work in the same small room with Lazear
for weeks and not know what Lazear was doing?
See p. 162
Sen. Doc.

Referring to Lazear's letter of September 8, 1900. Carroll was al-
ready absent, sick with yellow fever, and Reed was in the U.S., so Lazear
could not tell his confreres at the laboratory. I doubt if he told A[unclear]gramonte.
The doctors at the hospital knew that Carroll had been bitten by Lazear's
“birds” and they knew that he had yellow fever. They also knew about XY.
As I stated in the mms. Lazear did not give them many details, but wanted
to wait until Reed returned and let him, the president of the board, tell
what had happened. Lazear was not only loyal to his chief, but he also had
good common sense. There was a great responsibility resting on his
shoulders and naturally he cautioned his wife not to say anything.

I shall always adhere to the statements I made in the mms.viz:-
“He had grown to be more and more optomistic about getting results from
infected mosquitos”. As stated above that statement could be stronger.

Your inference is also wrong that I antedated myself in stating
that Wood had approved the Board's request to use Volunteers. Do you think
Reed or Lazear would have dared to take up the mosquito work and place in-
fected mosquitos on themselves or others without first obtaining the highest
military authority present in Cuba? Of course not. The thing that Wood
approved on October 12th, (Kean's diary) was permission to use Spanish
immigrants, if they gave their consent, and to pay them a gratuity. I have
never seen Kean's diary, but I am sure he will tell you that this was what
was intended, if the diary is not clear. Lazear failed to ask Pinto's
authority in XY's case, I think. I don't know that he notified the Post
Commander and asked his authority in the cases bitten during August, 1900,
listed in Table III, Preliminary Report. But I do know that General Wood
question
in (Jan 7
1942)
show
Pinto
Page Seven.
had approved of theirdoing it. Proper military procedure would also have
required Lazear to notify his Commanding Officer, Pinto, and the latter
should have then taken up the matter with the Post Commander. As this
was not done Reed listed Dean as XY in his Preliminary Report.

(34) I stated very definitely that they told me of Lazear's success
with infected mosquitos in the two cases (XY and Carroll) and that Lazear
was sick, presumably from the same cause. Perhaps I can amplify or get
additional information. I know of no official version regarding Dean's in-
occulation except that given in the Preliminary Report. Azgramonte's story
is not true as he himself stated in the quotations you published at W. & J.
and as Lazear wrote to his wife on September 8th. Lazear was “working en-
tirely alone.” In my opinion it is necessary for someone, yourself preferably,
to get Dr. Pinto's version on this point and many others. I have never
heard from him since leaving Cuba, but saw him once for a few minutes, in
Omaha, about 1906. I haven't an idea what he will say. If he is still
active mentally and physically he should be able to shed much light on many
points. He possibly feels that General Kean and I kept him from getting on
the Roll of Honor and on that account I have not asked him any questions.
I fully intended to do so before publishing my story. He may have important
records and photos. I will bet my hat that, if you can get him to talk free-
ly, he will confirm everything I have said about Azgramonte, Dean and Lazear.
He lives in Omaha, Nebraska. I do not know his address, but he was for a
long time the City Health Officer and so is, no doubt, well known. His full
name is Alva S. Pinto.

(35) I can not quote his exact words, but I can remember that he felt
and admitted that a mosquito might be responsible for his illness. He did
✓ ✓ not tell me about having been bitten at Las Animas. Of course, he was not re-
ferring to the bite recorded in Table III, as that was on August 16, a month
before I saw him - (September 18th).

(36) I can't remember. All I know about its disappearance, I geot from
Generals Ireland or Kean. In effect, I was told that Carroll had the book
after Reed's death and that it “disappeared mysteriously”. Perhaps Kean
can tell you more.

(38) The cemetery was a small piece of land used by our troops for tem-
porary interment of all U. S. deceased military personnel. All bodies were
disinterred and shipped home in due time. I can see why that was the best
way to handle the situation, but do not know why the Government did it that
way. The cemetery is not there, but the land is and some day, God willing,
I will visit the place and try to “put it on the map”. Q.M. maps should show
it!

(39) Nobody knows why Lazear did not promptly go on sick report. Poss-
ibly the initial symptoms were mild and he was doubtful of the diagnosis. He
was actually under observation by Ames when I reported for duty On Sept. 18th.
